passages.text: USA | Semiconductors
Blayne's Bytes: Earnings (P) reviews, Chicago Conference Takeaways

Coming back with our takeaways from a busy week at our 2025 Jefferies Semiconductor, IT Hardware & Communications Technology Summit. We held a joint call with EU Semis & Hardware Analyst Janardan Menon yesterday (replay link below). Also providing our views on NVDA/MRVL earnings from this week and AVGO print on Thursday next week.

2025 Chicago Conference Takeaways: Our annual conference just wrapped up with roughly 100 companies in attendance. Optical was the brightest area with LITE favored given a more incremental 800G/1.6T ramp vs COHR but both should see tailwinds. 200G/lane should also push more active cabling, which is a 2026 driver for both ACCs (MTSI and SMTC) and AECs (CRDO and ALAB). MTSI is one of our favorite names given strong ramps in A&D and Telco and this DC opportunity layering on top. The messaging from Analog remained constructive but with seasonality swinging negative, the broader recovery is likely a 2026 story. In SPE, AMAT did seem to be more of an anomaly with others not pointing to China weakness. LRXC sounded very confident in its competitive position with drivers such as Moly, but it's hard to avoid the Memory overhang for the group. Memory is the area where investors were the most negative as there are fears that a Samsung HBM qualification would likely cause an oversupply and NAND fears circle around a softer demand profile pushing pricing lower. Please see our full conference note HERE (including company specific breakdowns) and replay from our takeaways call HERE!

AVGO Preview - TPU Ramp Upside Alongside Continued Networking Growth: Setup looks positive into the quarter with Ironwood beginning to ramp in July and more significantly into October. We see potential for \(>\) 2B in upside to the Semi Solutions business, led by TPU sales approaching \(3 - 4B\) , networking strong across the board, and significant growth in the non- AI business given the significant upside in MRVL's Enterprise/Carrier businesses guiding up \(30\%\) in October. GMs could take a small hit from the increased ASIC mix but the Street of \(77.8\%\) seems reasonable if strength in Switching and Non- AI helps offset. Overall, we think positioning is mixed into the print with those seeking AI exposure with relative safety still involved, but others worried about the catalyst path moving forward while we wait for proof points on future AI ASIC ramps and the potential for growth next year in the Software business. The upside in the quarter should be seen positively, but we wouldn't expect to see any big updates to the ASIC roadmap which is driving the valuation.

NVDA Earnings - Roadmap Remains on Track with Upside from China: October guidance was in line with expectations but most importantly, the B300 rollout is progressing smoothly, Rubin timeline remains on track, and China licenses offer potential for additional revenue to October with upside pending demand outlook. While a select number of China- based customers have received licenses over the past few weeks, NVDA has not shipped any H20s based on those licenses. Sold \(\) 650\(to H20 to unrestricted customer outside of China with\) \ \(2.5\) B of H20 revenue to China possible if geopolitical issues reside. Overall demand remains strong with NVDA on track to achieve \(\) 4\(in Sovereign AI revenue this year with expectations for\) \ \(3 - 4T\) in total AI infrastructure spend by end of decade. Networking revenue tallied \(\) 7B\(with Spectrum - X revenue growing DD \% sequentially and is now at\) \ \(10B\) annualized run rate (vs \(\) 8B\(prior,\) +25\% \(Q/Q to\) \ \(2.5B\) with InfiniBand nearly doubling Q/Q as well. Overall, NVDA remains our Top Pick with plenty of runway for growth as demand signals remain robust and the roadmap remains on track. Please see our full earnings note HERE.

Source: FactSet, Jefferies Research

MRVL Earnings - Optical Trending Well but ASIC Visibility Remains Low: Optical is performing well (guided up DD % Q/Q in Q3) with Carrier/Enterprise expected to be up \(30\%\) in aggregate, but the focus continues to be the ASIC business which is expected to see lumpiness in Q3. The DC business is expected to be flat Q/Q (implying Custom business down DD % Q/Q) but Custom expected to grow in 2H vs 1H (implies significant bounce back in Q4). MRVL shifted to less customer specific commentary regarding ASIC programs at its AI day and therefore didn't reiterate that its lead ASIC customer will grow in C26. Nonetheless, progressing well on \(18+\) XPU sockets (vs 18 prior) with several already in volume production and announced scale- up switching opportunity in UAL and Ethernet for AI workloads. Initial volume shipments for 1.6T DSPs have already begun and the stronger optical market should be a continued tailwind for the business. Overall, we see the MSFT opportunity in late C26 as the much bigger story driver but Alchip share- loss concerns will continue until there is more visibility on the ASIC business. Please see our full earnings note HERE.
Company Valuation/Risks

Buy - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of \(15\%\) or more within a 12- month period. Hold - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of plus \(15\%\) or minus \(10\%\) within a 12- month period. Underperform - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of minus \(10\%\) or less within a 12- month period. The expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) for Buy rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) is \(20\%\) or more within a 12- month period as these companies are typically more volatile than the overall stock market. For Hold rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is plus or minus \(20\%\) within a 12- month period. For Underperform rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is minus \(20\%\) or less within a 12- month period.
NR - The investment rating and price target have been temporarily suspended. Such suspensions are in compliance with applicable regulations and/or Jefferies policies.
CS - Coverage Suspended. Jefferies has suspended coverage of this company.
NC - Not covered. Jefferies does not cover this company.

Restricted - Describes issuers where, in conjunction with Jefferies engagement in certain transactions, company policy or applicable securities regulations prohibit certain types of communications, including investment recommendations.
Monitor - Describes securities whose company fundamentals and financials are being monitored, and for which no financial projections or opinions on the investment merits of the company are provided.

Jefferies methodology for assigning ratings may include the following: market capitalization, maturity, growth/value, volatility and expected total return over the next 12 months. The price targets are based on several methodologies, which may include, but are not restricted to, analyses of market risk, growth rate, revenue stream, discounted cash flow (DCF), EBITDA, EPS, cash flow (CF), free cash flow (FCF), EV/EBITDA, P/E, PE/growth, P/CF, P/FCF, premium (discount)/average group EV/EBITDA, premium (discount)/average group P/E, sum of the parts, net asset value, dividend returns, and return on equity (ROE) over the next 12 months.

Jefferies Franchise Picks include stock selections from among the best stock ideas from our equity analysts over a 12 month period. Stock selection is based on fundamental analysis and may take into account other factors such as analyst conviction, differentiated analysis, a favorable risk/reward ratio and investment themes that Jefferies analysts are recommending. Jefferies Franchise Picks will include only Buy rated stocks and the number can vary depending on analyst recommendations for inclusion. Stocks will be added as new opportunities arise and removed when the reason for inclusion changes, the stock has met its desired return, if it is no longer rated Buy and/or if it triggers a stop loss. Stocks having 120 day volatility in the bottom quartile of S&P stocks will continue to have a 15% stop loss, and the remainder will have a 20% stop. Franchise Picks are not intended to represent a recommended portfolio of stocks and is not sector based, but we may note where we believe a Pick falls within an investment style such as growth or value.
